[[University of California, Berkeley|University of California]]
[[Harvard Law School]] |}'''R. Christopher "Chris" Barden''' (born 1954) Ph.D., J.D., L.P. is a [[scientist]], [[clinical psychologist]] and [[attorney-at-law|attorney]] who lives in [[Edina, Minnesota]]. He served as the director of the National Association for Consumer Protection In Mental Health Practices (NACPMHP) from 1995-2005. In 2005, the NACPMHP merged into the Commission for Scientific Medicine and Mental Health (CSMMH), a national health care consumer protection agency whose members include physicians, scientists and researchers.{{cite web|url=http://www.csmmh.org/fellows.html |title=CSMMH |publisher=CSMMH |date= |accessdate=2010-10-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100925212504/http://www.csmmh.org/fellows.html |archivedate=September 25, 2010 }} [[File:ChrisBarden.jpg|thumb|upright|Chris Barden in 2010]] ==Biography== ===Education=== Barden was educated at the Institute for Child Development at the [[University of Minnesota]], receiving his [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] [[Summa Cum Laude]], Distinguished Graduating Senior Award, in 1976. He attended graduate school at the [[University of California, Berkeley|University of California]] in [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]], the University of Minnesota, and the Palo Alto V.A./[[Stanford University Medical Center]], where he interned, receiving his [[Ph.D.]] in Child and Adult Clinical Psychology in 1982. He later attended [[Harvard Law School]] in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], receiving his [[juris doctor|J.D.]] [[cum laude]] in 1992. He became a licensed psychologist in Texas in 1984 and in Minnesota in 1988. He has been a licensed Minnesota attorney since 1992, and a certified Minnesota mediator since 1994.{{cite web|title=R. Christopher Barden, Ph.D., J.D., LP (Resume)|url=http://www.kidscomefirst.info/RCBResume.pdf |accessdate=April 20, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705022712/http://www.kidscomefirst.info/RCBResume.pdf |archivedate=July 5, 2008 }} ===Career=== R. Chris Barden, Ph.D., J.D., L.P. has worked as a scientist, psychologist, attorney, and expert witness. Barden has published in or edited journals and texts in child psychology, social psychology, clinical psychology, sports psychology, psychiatry, surgery, pediatrics, and law. He has testified as an expert witness in psychology, law, and scientific methodology in multiple federal and state courts. Barden has also helped draft and enact successful national health care legislation mandating reforms in the U.S. Emergency Medical System for Children.Barden, R. C., Kinscherff, R., George, W., Flyer, R., Seidel, J., & Henderson, D., (1993), Emergency Medical Care and Injury Prevention Systems for Children: An Economic-Medical-Legal-Psychological Analysis and Legislative Proposals, Harvard Journal on Legislation, Vol. 30, No. 2, pgs 461497. Barden has applied a multidisciplinary, litigation-policy team approach to institute reforms in the U.S. emergency medical, legal, and mental health systems. In 2006, Barden drafted an ''amicus curiae'' brief to the [[California Supreme Court]] signed by nearly 100 international experts in the fields of human memory, neuroscience, psychiatry, and psychology emphasizing the lack of credible scientific support for "repressed and recovered memories.Barden, R. C. Amicus Brief in Taus v. Loftus, Supreme Court of California, Feb. 21, 2006. Psychiatric Malpractice Cases Regarding "Repressed Memory Therapy" and "Multiple Personality Disorder" Barden has participated as an attorney, consultant, and expert witness in multiple malpractice lawsuits against therapists, and has spoken out against therapies such as “repressed and recovered memory therapies,”{{cite web|title=Truth and Responsibility in Mental Health Practices Act -- The Barden Letter|url=http://www.stopbadtherapy.com/reform/letter.shtml|accessdate=April 7, 2016|date=January 5, 1995|website=Stop Bad Therapy}} “rebirthing therapies”{{cite web|url=http://phtherapies.wordpress.com/2011/09/23/r-christopher-barden-defeats-junk-and-pseudoscience-in-the-courtroom/|title=R. Christopher Barden Defeats Junk and Pseudoscience in the Courtroom|author=Monica Pignotti|date=September 23, 2011|work=Potentially Harmful and Other Questionable Therapies|accessdate=April 8, 2016}} and “holding therapies.”{{cite web|title=DR. BARDEN'S RESPONSES TO SENATOR HELLEWELL'S QUESTIONS AND STATEMENTS|date=February 13, 2003|url=http://www.kidscomefirst.info/BardensResponse.pdf|deadurl=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031202214926/http://www.kidscomefirst.info/BardensResponse.pdf|archive-date=December 2, 2003|accessdate=April 7, 2016}} Consultant: Federal Bureau of Investigation, U.S. Attorneys Office,and Office of the Federal Public Defender State Prosecution Expert Witness, Colorado State Prosecution Expert Consultant, Washington State Prosecution Expert Witness, Texas State Prosecution Expert Consultant, Wisconsin State Office of the Public Defender (MN, WI, UT) Invited Training Speaker, American Bar Association Invited Training Speaker, American Psychological Association Invited Training Speaker, U.S. Surgeon Generalâ€™s Conference Invited Training Speaker, U.S. Military Academy, West Point, New York Invited Speaker at Harvard, Yale, Columbia, UC Berkeley, U of MN, U of TX, U of IA, U of GA, USC, SMU, Penn State, U of NC, etc Special Asst. Attorney General, State of Utah Member, Minnesota State Board of Psychology Member, Minnesota Higher Education Coordinating Board Intern, Harvard Medical School/Law School Forensic Program Intern, Attorney Generalâ€™s Office, State of Massachusetts Consultant to a number of states regarding Mental Health Professional Licensing Bd.Actions{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} ====Hamanne v. Humenansky (1994)==== Barden represented V. Hamanne in her suit against her former psychiatrist, Diane Humenansky, for implanting [[false memories]] of child abuse using “repressed memory therapy.”Gustafson, Paul. Jury awards patient $2.6 million: Verdict finds therapist Humenansky liable in repressed memory trial Minneapolis St. Paul Tribune, August 1, 1995Associated Press, False-Memory Patient Wins Suit, The Globe and Mail (Canada), Aug. 2, 1995. Expert witnesses Dr. Elizabeth Loftus and Dr. Richard Ofshe testified that repressed memory therapy was unsupported by scientific evidence and dangerous.Associated Press, Doctor Loses False-memory Suit, Chicago Tribune, Wed. Aug. 2, 1995, Sec. 1, pg. 12 The jury awarded Hamanne $2.6 Million for pain and suffering, lost earnings, and medical expenses. Dr. Humenansky license was later suspended.{{cite news|url=http://www.stopbadtherapy.com/resource/article/diane2.shtml|title=Board suspends license of psychiatrist Diane Humenansky|author=Paul Gustafson|date=February 8, 1997|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|accessdate=8 April 2016}} ====Carlson v. Humenansky (1996)==== Barden also represented E. Carlson in her suit against Dr. Humenansky for using “repressed memory therapy.{{cite news|url=http://www.citypages.com/1996-01-31/news/more-recovered-memory-woes/ |title=More Recovered Memory Woes |work=[[City Pages]] |date=January 31, 1996 |accessdate=April 8, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100930092008/http://www.citypages.com/1996-01-31/news/more-recovered-memory-woes/ |archivedate=September 30, 2010 |df= }}Guthrey, M. and Kaplan, T., 2nd Patient Wins Against Psychiatrist: Accusation of planting memories brings multi-million dollar verdict. St. Paul Pioneer Press, Jan. 25, 1996, 4B. ====Burgus v. Braun (1997)==== Barden represented P. Burgess in her malpractice suit against Dr. Bennett Braun. Burgess claimed that Braun’s use of repressed memory therapy and his diagnosis of “multiple personality disorder” caused them severe emotional, psychological, and financial harm. The case was settled in 1997 for a record $10.6 Million. A wave of international media attention from this case—including a page 1, col. 1 story in the NYTimes—was instrumental in subsequent mental health reforms.[Belluck, P. She Recovered Memories, Then Millions in Damages, The New York Times, pg 1, col 1, Nov 9, 1997][Keenan, M., "The Devil and Dr. Braun," New City, Chicago, IL, June 22, 1995] ==== Reform litigation regarding "Rebirthing Therapy" and Coercive "Holding Therapy" ==== "REBIRTHING THERAPY": Barden joined forces with the national media as well as prosecutors and legislators in Colorado to end “rebirthing therapy” in the U.S.See, Rouse, Karen. Rebirthing verdict may curb restraint therapy. Denver Post, April 22, 2001 See, Lowe, Peggy. Ethics specialist blasts 'rebirthing'. Rocky Mountain News, April 13, 2001. "It's easily the most reckless and abusive treatment of a child I've ever seen," said Christopher Barden, a psychologist and lawyer who specializes in psychotherapy abuse cases. Barden testified for Jefferson County prosecutors in their criminal case against Evergreen therapists Connell Watkins and Julie Ponder. The pair are charged in connection with the April 18 rebirthing session that killed Candace Newmaker, a 10-year-old adopted girl from North Carolina.” ; See, Janofsky, M. Girl's Death Brings Ban on Kind of 'Therapy'. New York Times. April 18, 2001; Peggy Lowe, Rebirthing team convicted: Two therapists face mandatory terms of 16 to 48 years in jail, Rocky Mountain News, April 21, 2001. COERCIVE "HOLDING THERAPY": Barden was appointed Special Assistant Attorney General in Utah to assist in the prosecution of “coercive attachment” therapists. Joint litigation and legislative efforts closed the clinic and ended these practices. See, Santini, J., Legislative Panel Backs Measure That Would Ban 'Holding Therapy', The Salt Lake Tribune, September 20, 2002, Friday, at Pg. A10. "Before voting to support the measure, the Child Welfare Oversight Panel on Thursday considered testimony from Christopher Barden, an expert in child psychology, who called coercive therapy "quackery." {{for|the 58 album|Diet for a New America (album)}} {{italic title}} '''''Diet for a New America''''' is a 1987 bestselling book by [[John Robbins (author)|John Robbins]].<ref name=robbins>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/02/garden/eating-well.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|title=Eating Well|newspaper=The New York Times|author=Marian Burros|date=December 2, 1992}}</ref> The book discusses [[vegetarianism]], the environmental impact of [[factory farming]] and [[animal rights]].<ref name=robbins />
In 1991 [[KCET]], the Los Angeles [[PBS]] affiliate, produced a film documentary based on the book called ''Diet for a New America: Your Health, Your Planet''.<ref name=KCET>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1991-09-16/entertainment/ca-1811_1_beef-council|title=KCET's 'Diet' Isn't Savory for Beef, Dairy Industries|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|author=Sharon Bernstein|date=September 16, 1991}}</ref> The film is narrated by John Robbins and features interviews with [[Michael Klaper]], [[T. Colin Campbell]], and [[John A. McDougall]].<ref>{{cite video| people=John Robbins|title=Diet for a New America: Your Health, Your Planet|url=https://archive.org/details/DietForANewAmerica |medium=Documentary|publisher=[[KCET]] (PBS)|location= |date=1991}}</ref>
==Critical reception== [[Colman McCarthy]] and [[Cleveland Amory]] compared the book to [[Rachel Carson]]'s ''[[Silent Spring]]''.<ref name=robbins /><ref name=mccarthy>{{cite news|url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2011/Geneva%20NY%20Finger%20Lake%20Times/Geneva%20NY%20Finger%20Lake%20Times%201988%20Aug%201988/Geneva%20NY%20Finger%20Lake%20Times%201988%20Aug%201988%20-%200220.pdf|title=A Calmer, Rational Approach|newspaper=Finger Lakes Times|author=[[Colman McCarthy]]|date=August 6, 1988|quote=Robbins has written a book that is the pioneering match of Aldo Leopold's ''Sand County Almanac'', John Rawls' ''A Theory of Justice'', and Rachel Carson's ''Silent Spring''}}</ref> In an editorial for ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and ''Finger Lakes Times'' McCarthy writes: "Robbins has written a book that is the pioneering match of Aldo Leopold's ''[[A Sand County Almanac|Sand County Almanac]]'', John Rawls' ''[[A Theory of Justice]]'', and Rachel Carson's ''Silent Spring''."<ref name=mccarthy />
[[Marian Burros]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' writes: "Much of what Mr. Robbins has to say about diet in this country is unremarkable: we eat too much meat and dairy products. Much of what Mr. Robbins has to say about the inhumane treatment of animals on [[intensive animal farming|factory farms]] is correct. But Mr. Robbins undermines his case by exaggerating; facts mix with factoids and anecdotes."<ref name=robbins/>

In the United States a '''Doctor of Physical Therapy''' ('''DPT''') degree is now an entry level professional degree. A DPT is a practitioner who is educated in many areas of rehabilitation. However, a Doctor of Physical Therapy is not a medical doctor and can't prescribe medications in some countries like the United Kingdom. A Transitional Doctor of Physical Therapy Degree is also offered for those who already hold a professional Bachelor or Master of Physical Therapy (BPT or MPT) degree. As of 2015, all accredited and developing physical therapist programs are DPT programs.<ref name=autogenerated4>http://www.capteonline.org/uploadedFiles/CAPTEorg/State_Boards/MasterListofAccreditedPTPrograms.pdf#search=%22DPT%22</ref> The DPT degree currently prepares students to be eligible for the PT license examination in all 50 states. Along with the license examination, some states do require physical therapists to take a law exam and a criminal background check. As of March 2017, there are 222 accredited Doctor of Physical Therapy programs in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aptaapps.apta.org/accreditedschoolsdirectory/default.aspx?UniqueKey=|title=Accredited Schools Directory|website=aptaapps.apta.org}}</ref> After completing a DPT program the doctor of physical therapy may continue training in a [[residency (medicine)|residency]] and then fellowship. As of December 2013, there are 178 credentialed physical therapy residencies and 34 fellowships in the US <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abptrfe.org/home.aspx|title=ABPTRFE|first=Brightfind2|last=Brightfind2|website=www.abptrfe.org}}</ref> with 63 additional developing residencies and fellowships.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abptrfe.org/apta/abptrfe/Directory.aspx?navID=10737432672|title=Directory of Residency Programs|publisher=}}</ref> Credentialed residencies are between 9 and 36 months while credentialed fellowships are between 6 and 36 months.
In 2000 the [[American Physical Therapy Association]] (APTA) passed its ''Vision 2020'' statement, which states (in part):
: "By 2020, physical therapy will be provided by physical therapists who are doctors of physical therapy, recognized by consumers and other health care professionals as the practitioners of choice to whom consumers have direct access for the diagnosis of, interventions for, and prevention of impairments, functional limitations, and disabilities related to movement, function, and health."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.apta.org/Vision2020/ |title=Vision 2020 |publisher=American Physical Therapy Association |date=2011-10-04 |accessdate=2012-02-19}}</ref>
As this statement highlights, the DPT program is an integral part of the APTA's continued advocacy for legislation granting consumers (''i.e.'' patients and clients) direct access to physical therapists, rather than requiring physician referral. Direct access is said to decrease wait times for access to care and even help reduce both cost to consumer and overall healthcare costs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://elmwoodpark.suntimes.com/news/politics/10606269-418/direct-access-to-physical-therapists-being-sought.html |title=Direct access to physical therapists being sought |work=Elm Leaves |date=2012-02-12 |accessdate=2012-02-19}}</ref> As of January 1, 2015, all 50 states and the District of Columbia currently allow some form of direct access to physical therapists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apta.org/Media/Releases/Legislative/2014/7/1/|title=Michigan Grants Patients Direct Access to Physical Therapists|first=Kelly|last=Gardner|website=www.apta.org}}</ref>
==History of the DPT degree== In 1992, the [[University of Southern California]] initiated the first post-professional "transitional" (DPT) program in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sacm.org/MedicalUnit/PhysicalTherapy.aspx|title=Physical Therapy:<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=}}</ref> This "transitional" DPT takes into account a physiotherapist's current level of knowledge and skill and purports to offer programs that upgrade clinical skills to meet the needs of the current health care environment.<ref>The Postprofessional Clinical Doctorates [Draft Document]. Consensus Conference on Postprofessional Education. Alexandria, Va: American Physical Therapy Association; 1998.</ref><ref>Massey B. 2001 APTA Presidential Address: We have arrived! Phys Ther. 2001;81:1830- 1833.</ref> [[Creighton University]] followed by initiating the first entry-level DPT program in 1993.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spahp.creighton.edu/admission/dpt/doctor-of-physical-therapy|title=Doctor of Physical Therapy|date=8 April 2016|website=spahp.creighton.edu}}</ref><ref>Murphy W. Healing the Generations: A History of Physical Therapy and the American Physical Therapy Association. Alexandria, Va: American Physical Therapy Association; 1995.</ref>
The Doctor of Physiotherapy has since been adopted in other countries such as the United Kingdom, Australia and Taiwan. In the United Kingdom and Australia the PhD or Professional Doctorate in Physiotherapy is offered by a number of Universities. These programmes are usually professional entry masters level programmes with the opportunity to undertake research to lead to a doctorate degree. Alternatively, these programmes are masters pre-qualifying Physiotherapy courses with an enhanced research element in the final phase of the course that leads to undertaking a doctorate. The first full pre-qualifying Doctorate in Physiotherapy programme in the United Kingdom was accredited in 2017 at [[Glasgow Caledonian University]] in [[Glasgow]].
==Time frame==
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Undergraduate !! Doctor of Physical Therapy !! Residency (optional) !! Fellowship (optional) |- | 4 years || 3–4 years<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pt.cphs.wayne.edu/dptcurric.php|title=Physical Therapy - Wayne State University|first=Wayne State University Web|last=Communications|website=pt.cphs.wayne.edu}}</ref><ref>http://www.oakland.edu/upload/docs/SHS/PT/2011DPTBrochure%20.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.northeastern.edu/bouve/pt/pdf/Post%20Baccalaureate%20DPT%20Curriculum%20Plan%20-%2011-9-11.pdf</ref><ref name=autogenerated5>{{cite web|url=http://www.shu.edu/academics/gradmeded/doctor-physical-therapy/|title=Doctor of Physical Therapy (D.P.T.) - Seton Hall University|website=www.shu.edu}}</ref> || 9 to 36 months<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|title=www.apta.org|url=http://www.apta.org/uploadedFiles/APTAorg/Educators/Residency_and_Fellowship/Developing_Programs/RoleofResidencyTraining.pdf#search=%22time%20length%20for%20credentialed%20residencies%22|accessdate=2012-07-18}}</ref> || 6 to 36 months<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite web|url=http://www.apta.org/ResidencyFellowship/ResidencyvsFellowship/|title=Residency vs. Fellowship<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=}}</ref> |}
The typical time frame for completion of a Doctor of Physical Therapy is 3 to 4 years after earning a bachelor's degree. Depending on residency and fellowship training, if undertaken, the doctor may have completed several years of additional training. Obtaining a DPT could also be done by accelerated programs offered by some universities that can be applied to by freshman. These programs give students the opportunity receive a bachelor's degree and DPT in 6- to 7- years.With these programs, there are various admission points over the course of their curriculum. Various programs allow students to apply directly out of high school and they will automatically matriculate into the professional phase of the program after completing the required undergraduate courses.<ref>http://www.capteonline.org/uploadedFiles/CAPTEorg/About_CAPTE/Resources/Aggregate_Program_Data/AggregateProgramData_PTPrograms.pdf</ref>
==Admission==
Admission to a Doctor of Physical Therapy program in the USA is highly competitive. According to the Aggregate Program Data Report from CAPTE from 2016-2017, the average GPA for enrolling students was 3.6<ref name=CAPTE17>{{cite web |url=http://www.capteonline.org/uploadedFiles/CAPTEorg/About_CAPTE/Resources/Aggregate_Program_Data/AggregateProgramData_PTPrograms.pdf |title=2016-2017 Aggregate Program Data|publisher=Commission on Accreditation of Physical Therapy Education |date=March 10, 2017|accessdate=2018-01-24 |page=17}}</ref> with a range of 3.10 - 3.88 for all programs.<ref name=CAPTE17/> On average there were 500 applicants per program with an average of 46 students enrolled<ref name=CAPTE17/> A bachelor's degree generally is required before beginning a Doctor of Physical Therapy program, but there is no requirement on the degree earned, as long as all prerequisite course requirements are met.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apta.org/ProspectiveStudents/Admissions/PTProcess/|title=Physical Therapist (PT) Admissions Process|first=Libby|last=Ross|website=www.apta.org}}</ref> Obtaining a DPT could also be done by accelerated programs by some universities that can be applied by freshman. Through these programs students can receive a bachelor's degree and a DPT in 6- to 7- years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bls.gov/ooh/healthcare/physical-therapists.htm#tab-4|title=Physical Therapists : Occupational Outlook Handbook: : U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics|website=www.bls.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-10-06}}</ref> During the admission process into schools, one must fulfill the course prerequisites of the program. Students also must obtain physical therapy experience from clinics with hours that might have to be verified by a physical therapist depending on the school they are applying to. The Graduate Record Examination(GRE) must be taken and submitted to the school.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.apta.org/ProspectiveStudents/Admissions/PTProcess/|title=Physical Therapist (PT) Admissions Process|last=Ross|first=Libby|website=www.apta.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>
==Transition Doctor of Physical Therapy degree==
The t-DPT degree is conferred upon completion of a structured postprofessional educational experience that results in the augmentation of knowledge, skills, and behaviors to a level consistent with the current professional (entry-level) DPT standards. The t-DPT degree enables the US-licensed physical therapist to attain degree parity with therapists who hold the professional DPT by filling in any gaps between their professional baccalaureate or master's degree PT education and the current professional DPT degree education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apta.org/PostprofessionalDegree/TransitionDPTFAQs/|title=FAQ: Postprofessional DPT (Transition)|first=Kelly|last=Gardner|website=www.apta.org}}</ref>
The post-professional DPT (Transitional) degree is designed to provide the doctoral credential to those who currently holding a master's or bachelor's degree in the field. Post-professional DPT (Transitional) degree programs are typically offered on a primarily online learning model and are often one year in length.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.apta.org/PostprofessionalDegree/TransitionDPTFAQs/ |title=FAQ:Postprofessional DPT (Transition) |publisher=American Physical Therapy Association |date=2011-03-01 |accessdate=2012-02-19}}</ref>
==Controversies== The use of the title ''doctor'' by physical therapists and other non-physician health care professionals is controversial.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/02/health/policy/02docs.html?_r=2&ref=health |title=When the Nurse Wants to Be Called ‘Doctor’ |work=The New York Times |date=2011-10-01 |accessdate=2012-02-19}}</ref> In a letter to ''[[The New York Times]]'', the president of the American Physical Therapy Association responded:
: "To provide accurate information to consumers, the American Physical Therapy Association has taken a proactive approach and provides clear guidelines for physical therapists regarding the use of the title "Doctor." These guidelines state that physical therapists, in all clinical settings, who hold a Doctor of Physical Therapy degree (DPT) shall indicate they are physical therapists when using the title "Doctor" or "Dr," and shall use the titles in accord with jurisdictional law."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.apta.org/Media/Letters/2011/10/5/ |title=APTA Responds to The New York Times on Physical Therapists Using the Term 'Doctor' |publisher=American Physical Therapy Association |date=2011-10-05 |accessdate=2012-02-19}}</ref>
The DPT degree has been described as an example of "credential creep" or degree inflation in ''The Chronicle of Higher Education''. Citing concerns that the DPT, and similar professional doctorates in areas such as [[occupational therapy]], do not meet the standards of traditional doctorate degrees, the journal states: "The six-and-a-half-year doctor of physical therapy, or DPT, is rapidly replacing a six-year master's degree ... The American Physical Therapy Association ... has not set separate requirements for doctoral programs. To be accredited they need only to meet the same requirements as master's programs."<ref name=creep>{{cite web |url=http://www.csun.edu/pubrels/clips/June07/06-18-07M.pdf |title=Credential Creep |work=The Chronicle of Higher Education |date=2007-06-27 |accessdate=2012-02-19}}</ref>
Critics question whether the rigor of the physical therapy curriculum and the current scope of practice warrant the conferral of a professional degree similar to that characteristic of medicine, dentistry, or nursing.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://ptjournal.apta.org/content/79/10/978.full |last=Messaros |first=A |title=Fatal assumption [letter to the editor] |journal=Physical Therapy |date=October 1999 |volume=79 |issue=10 |pages=981–982}}</ref> Proponents counter that the existing curricula are "victims of 'curricular inflation'."<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://ptjournal.apta.org/content/79/10/978.full |last1=Threlkeld |first1=A |last2=Jensen |first2=G |last3=Royeen |first3=C |title=Author response |journal=Physical Therapy |date=October 1999 |volume=79 |issue=10 |pages=986–990}}</ref> As Rothstein<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://ptjournal.apta.org/content/78/4/358.full.pdf |last=Rothstein |first=J |title=Education at the Crossroads: For Today's Practice, the DPT [editorial] |journal=Physical Therapy |date=April 1998 |volume=78 |issue=4 |pages=358–360}}</ref> and Moffat<ref>Moffat M. APTA Presidential Address: Will the legacy of our past provide us with a legacy for the future? Phys Ther. 1994;74:1063-1066.</ref> noted, the previous master's and even baccalaureate curricula rival that of most other doctoral programs, and these curricula often require more than the typical 72 credits mandated for a doctoral degree.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://ptjournal.apta.org/content/78/11/1208.full.pdf |last=Sahrmann |first=S |title=Moving Precisely? Or Taking the Path of Least Resistance? |journal=Physical Therapy |date=November 1998 |volume=78 |issue=11 |pages=1208–1218}}</ref> The 2000 Fact Sheet from APTA reported that the mean number of credits required for the professional phase of the typical baccalaureate program was 83.0 credits and that the typical master's degree program required 95.5 credits.<ref>2000 Fact Sheet: Physical Therapist Education Program. Alexandria, Va: American Physical Therapy Association; October 2000.</ref> As of 2009 the typical number of prerequisite credits was 114.2 and the total number of professional credits was 116.5 for a total of 230.7 credit hours.<ref>2009 fact sheet: Physical Therapist Education Program. Alexandria, Va: American Physical Therapy Association; August 2009</ref> This is well in excess of the typical 72 professional credits mandated for a doctoral degree. Additional credit hours may be earned in residency and fellowship as well. Threlkeld et al.<ref>Threlkeld A. Jensen G, Royeen C [author response]. PhysTher. 1999:79:986-990.</ref> suggest that the scope of existing physical therapy curricula already matches that of a professional doctorate, further submitting that students of a well-defined DPT program will have earned the right to be recognized with the doctoral title.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paeaonline.org/index.php?ht=a/GetDocumentAction/i/69169|title=Physician Assistant Education Association|website=Physician Assistant Education Association}}</ref>
== Professional degree (entry-level) == The professional (entry-level) DPT degree is currently the degree conferred by all physical therapist professional programs upon successful completion of a three- to four-year post-baccalaureate degree program in the [[United States]], preparing the graduate to enter the practice of physical therapy. Admission requirements for the program include completion of an undergraduate degree that includes specific prerequisite coursework, volunteer experience (or other exposure to the profession), and completion of a standardized graduate examination (e.g., [[GRE]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pt.usc.edu/sublayout.aspx?menu_id=52&id=72|title=DPT - Frequently Asked Questions - USC Division of Biokinesiology and Physical Therapy<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=}}</ref>
Typical prerequisite courses may include two semesters of anatomy and physiology with labs, two semesters of physics with labs, two semesters of chemistry with labs, a general course in psychology, another course in psychology, statistics, two semesters of biology,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cumc.columbia.edu/dept/pt/prospective/elp/admissions.html|title=Columbia University Program in Physical Therapy<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=}}</ref> and may include other courses required by specific schools.
The physical therapist curriculum consists of foundational sciences (i.e., [[gross anatomy]], cellular [[histology]], [[embryology]], [[neurology]], [[neuroscience]], [[kinesiology]], [[physiology]], [[exercise physiology]], [[pathology]], [[pharmacology]], [[radiology]]/[[Medical imaging|imaging]], [[medical screening]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://catalog.apu.edu/graduate/behavioral-applied-sciences/physical-therapy/physical-therapy-phd/|title=Doctor of Physical Therapy (DPT) Coursework — Azusa Pacific University|publisher=}}</ref>), [[behavioral sciences]] (communication, social and psychologic factors, ethics and values, law, business and management sciences, clinical reasoning and evidence-based practice<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.georgefox.edu/physical-therapy/academics/curriculum.html|title=Program Requirements - Physical Therapy Program - George Fox University|website=www.georgefox.edu}}</ref>), and clinical sciences (cardiovascular/pulmonary, endocrine and metabolic, gastrointestinal and [[genitourinary]], [[integumentary]], [[musculoskeletal]], neuromuscular). Coursework also includes material specific to the practice of physical therapy (patient/client management model, prevention, wellness, and health promotion, practice management, management of care delivery, social responsibility, advocacy, and core values). Additionally, students have to engage in full-time clinical practice under the supervision of licensed physical therapists with an expectation of providing safe, competent, and effective physical therapy.
== Continuing Education == Post-graduation, licensed physical therapists have the ability to pursue a clinical residency or fellowship to expand their knowledge and experience. Clinical residencies are designed to further a physical therapy resident's knowledge in a specific area of clinical practice. A clinical fellowship is a program for physical therapists in an area of the specific focus.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.abpts.org/Certification/|title=Specialist Certification|last=Mendenhall|first=Keith|website=www.abpts.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>
Physical therapists also have the ability to pursue speciality certifications, where they become board certified clinical specialists. Becoming a certified specialist allows the therapist to earn credentials that represents further dedication to patient care. It gives the opportunity for professional growth and positions in leadership and service. This specialization is done by building a broad foundation of professional education then building a skillset related to the particular specialization area. The certifications given in the specific areas are: cardiovascular and pulmonary, clinical electrophysiology, geriatrics, neurology, orthopedics, pediatrics, sports physical therapy, and women's health.<ref name=":0" />
Physical therapists can provide various modalities of treatment for the patient. The modalities include: ultrasound, electrical stimulation, traction, joint mobilization, massage, heat, ice, kinesiology taping, and many more. Forms of treatment depends on the therapists preference of treatment and the clinics equipment availability. Based on the patient, specific types of treatment might be better suited. Therapists might also find different modalities not as effective as others. However, some modalities might not be possible due to the clinics restrictions on space and equipment availability.<ref name=":0" />
== Advanced clinical science degree == The "advanced clinical science" doctorate (e.g., DPTSc or DScPT, [[DHSc]], ScDPT) is one of several degrees conferred by academic institutions upon successful completion of a post-professional physical therapist education program. This program is intended to provide an experienced clinician with advanced knowledge, clinical skills, and professional behavior, usually in a specific specialty practice area. These programs typically culminate work that contributes new knowledge to clinical practice in the profession. Completion of these advanced clinical science doctoral programs may include credentialed clinical residencies and lead to ABPTS clinical specialization or other advanced certifications.
== United Kingdom == [[Glasgow Caledonian University]] in [[Glasgow]] is the first in the United Kingdom to offer a 3.5 year [https://www.gcu.ac.uk/study/courses/details//index.php/P03131 Doctorate in Physiotherapy] (pre-registration) programme which is the first clinical doctorate which leads to qualification as a Physiotherapist eligible to register with the [[Chartered Society of Physiotherapy|CSP]] and [[Health and Care Professions Council|HCPC]] in the United Kingdom. This programme provides a focus on researcher development as well as professional development within a [[Health and Social Care|health and social care]] context. Some UK universities offer a DPT as a post-professional qualification, but the qualifying degree remains Bachelor or Master of Science in Physiotherapy (with honours). This is offered at the [[University of Sussex]] in [[Brighton]], Nottingham University and Robert Gordon University.

'''Elma Sandford-Morgan''' (23 February 1890 – 1983) was an Australian physician who practised medicine in India and Iraq during the 1920s.
Elma Linton Sandford (later Mrs Sandford-Morgan) was born in [[Adelaide|Adelaide, South Australia]] in 1890.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Elma Linton Sandford-Morgan|last=Ogilvie|first=Marilyn and Harvey, Joy|publisher=Routledge|year=1999|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Her father, [[Alexander Wallace Sandford]], a businessman and politician, died in 1905. She was educated at a number of girls schools, before entering [[Cheltenham Ladies' College|Cheltenham Ladies College]] in 1905.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article73742870|title=DR E. S. MORGAN.|date=1929-03-08|work=The Advertiser|location=Adelaide|access-date=2017-06-08|pages=15}}</ref> Her mother supported her decision to study medicine, and Sandford enrolled at the [[University of Sydney]] in 1910. She graduated with her M.D. in 1917.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article129004244|title=ABC OF MOTHERCRAFT|date=1930-05-31|work=The News|location=Adelaide|access-date=2017-06-08|pages=3}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15755823|title=UNIVERSITY OF SYDNEY.|date=1917-09-05|work=Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=2017-06-08|pages=10}}</ref>
== Career == Sandford was appointed a resident medical officer at the [[Royal Alexandra Hospital for Children|Royal Alexandra Hospital]] for Children in Sydney, and she then became senior medical registrar at the [[Royal Prince Alfred Hospital]]. She travelled to England in 1919 to study ophthalmology at the London hospitals.<ref name=":1" /> It was there that she heard about the urgent need for doctors in India to combat eye disease.<ref name=":0" /> She worked for a year at the Bhiwani Mission Women's Hospital around 1920, before taking a position in [[Baghdad]] at a hospital for women and children.<ref name=":2" /> It was in Baghdad, that she met British Army Officer Harry Morgan, and they were married in 1921. She worked in private practice in Baghdad<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article4333709|title=WOMEN'S VIEWS AND NEWS.|date=1924-06-06|access-date=2017-06-08|pages=16}}</ref> until their daughter, Rosemary was born in 1922.
The Sandford-Morgans returned to Australia in 1923, and Dr Sandford-Morgan worked mainly in private practice, or for the Public Health Service in Hobart and Sydney. Their son, Gavin was born in 1925. Captain Morgan and Dr Sandford-Morgan separated, and she moved to Adelaide with their children around 1937.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article45674460|title=Roundabout|date=1950-11-03|work=The Advertiser|location=Adelaide|access-date=2017-06-08|pages=13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article117230415|title=DR. SANDFORD MORGAN|date=1937-04-08|work=Farmer and Settler|location=Sydney|access-date=2017-06-08|pages=16}}</ref> She was a director and developer of a Mothercraft training school.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article224261445|title=Dr. Sandford Morgan's Book|date=1930-05-25|work=The Sun|location=Sydney|access-date=2017-06-08|pages=39}}</ref> At a meeting of the [[Australian Federation of University Women]] in 1938, comments she made about women graduates and motherhood, made the national newspapers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article29215545|title=University Women|date=1938-01-25|work=The Mercury|location=Hobart, Tas.|access-date=2017-06-08|pages=10}}</ref>
== World War II == Sandford-Morgan assisted the Royal Australian Air Force Medical Service during World War II.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/people/736099?q=%22dr+elma+sandford-morgan%22&c=people|title=Sandford-Morgan, Elma (1890-1983) - People and organisations|website=Trove|language=en|access-date=2017-06-08}}</ref> She was appointed to a parliamentary commission investigating health services in South Australia at the close of the war.<ref name=":0" /> She wished to take up a position in Europe, and accepted a role as a medical officer at the Commonwealth Immigration camp in New South Wales.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article45794379|title=About People|date=1951-12-22|access-date=2017-06-08|pages=11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article45689834|title=Enjoying Her Job At Migrant Centre|date=1951-03-28|access-date=2017-06-08|pages=11}}</ref> However, the transfer that was offered with this role to a European practice, was denied her as a woman.<ref name=":0" /> She resigned and sought employment on her own.<ref name=":0" />
== Later life == Sandford-Morgan returned to private practice in Australia, and then worked as a neoplasm registrar at the Anticancer Foundation of the University of Adelaide. She continued working until the age of 74 and thereafter volunteered at the Red Cross Blood Transfusion Service until she was 80.
Sandford-Morgan was President of the Medical Women's Society of South Australia.<ref name=":0" />
Elma Sandford-Morgan died in 1983. She was survived by her children. She is remembered for her pioneering work as a doctor.

'''Flexibility''' is a [[personality trait]] that describes the extent to which a person can [[Coping (psychology)|cope]] with changes in circumstances and think about problems and tasks in novel, creative ways.<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cpc7CJH1-s8C&pg=PA731 |title=Encyclopedia of creativity |volume=1 |chapter=Flexibility |author=Becky Thurston, Mark Runco|isbn=9780122270758 |date=August 1999 }}</ref> This trait is used when stressors or unexpected events occur, requiring a person to change their stance, outlook, or commitment. Flexible personality should not be confused with [[cognitive flexibility]], which is the ability to switch between two concepts, as well as simultaneously think about multiple concepts. Researchers of cognitive flexibility describe it as the ability to switch one's thinking and attention between tasks.<ref name="Miyake">{{cite journal|last=Miyake|first=A|author2=Friedman, N P |author3=Emerson, M J. |author4=Witzki, A H |author5=Howerter, A |author6= Wagner, T |title=The unity and diversity of executive functions and their contributions to complex "frontal lobe" tasks: A latent variable analysis|journal=Cognitive Psychology|year=2000|volume=41|pages=49–100|doi=10.1006/cogp.1999.0734|pmid=10945922 |issue=1}}</ref> Flexibility, or '''psychological flexibility''', as it is sometimes referred to, is the ability to adapt to situational demands, balance life demands, and commit to behaviors.
==Measures/assessments== Due to the different facets of the definition of psychological flexibility, there are many problems when measuring it. There are multiple questionnaires that attempt to do so.
===Acceptance and Action Questionnaire=== The Acceptance and Action Questionnaire (AAQ) was developed in order to measure [[experiential avoidance]]. This test found that higher levels of avoidance were linked to higher levels of general psychopathology, depression, anxiety, fears, and a lower quality of life. It also measured avoidant coping and self-deceptive positivity.<ref name="Hayes">{{cite journal|last1=Hayes|first1=Steven|author2=Kirk Strosahl|author3=Kelly Wilson|author4=Richard Bissett|author5=Jacqueline Pistorello|author6=Dosheen Toarmino|author7=Melissa Polusny|author8=Thane Dykstra|author9=Sonja Batten|author10=John Bergan|author11=Sherry Stewart|author12=Michael Zvolensky|author13=Georg Eifert|author14=Frank Bond|author15=John Forsyth|author16=Maria Karekla|author17=Susan McCurry|title=Measuring Experiential Avoidance: A Preliminary Test of a Working Model|journal=The Psychological Record|date=2004|volume=54|issue=4|pages=553–578|url=http://opensiuc.lib.siu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1359&context=tpr}}</ref> It was later decided that the AAQ actually measured psychological flexibility, not experiential avoidance.<ref name="Hayesagain">{{cite web|last=Hayes|first=Steven|title=Acceptance & Action Questionnaire (AAQ) and Variations|url=http://contextualscience.org/acceptance_action_questionnaire_aaq_and_variations|publisher=Association for Contextual Behavioral Science}}</ref> It was used until the AAQ-II was created. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Acceptance and Action Questionnaire.png|thumb|Figure 1. Acceptance and Action Questionnaire<ref name="Hayes" />]] -->
===Acceptance and Action Questionnaire II=== The AAQ-II was developed in order to improve upon the faults of the AAQ. The original AAQ had faults in scale brevity, item wording, and item selection procedures that caused insufficient alpha levels to be obtained in measurements.<ref name="Hayesagain" /> The AAQ-II scores were found to predict many outcomes, including mental health and work absence rates. The AAQ-II also was found to be more psychometrically consistent than the original AAQ.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bond|first=F.W. |author2=S.C. Hayes |author3=R.A. Baer |author4=K.M. Carpenter |author5=N. Guenole |author6=H.K. Orcutt |author7=T. Waltz |author8=R.D. Zettle|title=Preliminary psychometric properties of the acceptance and action questionnaire-ii: A revised measure of psychological inflexibility and experiential avoidance|journal=Behavior Therapy|date=2011|volume=42|issue=4|pages=676–688|doi=10.1016/j.beth.2011.03.007}}</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Acceptance and Action Quesionnaire - II-1.fw.png|thumb|Figure 2. Acceptance and Action Questionnaire II<ref>{{cite web|title=Acceptance and Action Questionnaire (AAQ-II)|url=http://www.newharbingeronline.com/excerpts/realBehaviorChangePrimaryCare/appdxa.pdf}}</ref>]] -->
Laboratory measures of flexibility are consistent with how flexible people are in their actual lives. Flexibility measured in laboratory settings even predicted how flexible people will be in real life.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cheng|first=C.|title=Assessing Coping Flexibility in Real-life and Laboratory Settings: A Multimethod Approach|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|date=2001|volume=80|issue=5|pages=814–833|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.80.5.814}}</ref> More recently however, the validity of the AAQ has again been brought into question, primarily by inconsistent results. Recent studies have shown that both versions of the AAQ appear to measure the same thing, which is neuroticism/negative affect rather than experiential avoidance.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.beth.2017.08.008 | title=Experiential Avoidance: An Examination of the Construct Validity of the AAQ-II and MEAQ | year=2017 | journal=Behavior Therapy | last1 = Rochefort | first1 = Catherine | last2 = Baldwin | first2 = Austin S. | last3 = Chmielewski | first3 = Michael}}</ref>
==Impacts on life==
===Parent–child relationships=== Research has shown that the relationship between parent and child distress may be influenced by parenting psychological flexibility.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Moyer|first=D.N.|author2=E.K. Sandoz|title=The role of psychological flexibility in the relationship between parent and adolescent distress|journal=Journal of Child and Family Studies|date=2014|doi=10.1007/s10826-014-9947-y|volume=24|issue=5|pages=1406–1418}}</ref> When parents are psychologically inflexible they cause more stress in their families. A similar study looked at the longitudinal relationship between perceived parenting style and psychological flexibility among students over six years (7th–12th [[Grading in education|grade]]). Results showed that psychological flexibility decreased with age, illustrating that as children grow older they become more set in their thoughts and habits, being less likely to change them due to circumstances. Results also indicated that [[Parenting styles#Authoritarian parenting|authoritarian parenting styles]] predicted low psychological flexibility in children. This demonstrates that parents who over-control their children tend to restrict how well their children cope with stressors in life. Lastly, results showed that children with psychological flexibility in 9th grade were more likely to have decreases in authoritarian and increases in authoritative parenting style later on.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Williams|first=K.E. |author2=J. Ciarrochi |author3=P.C. Heaven|title=Inflexible Parents, Inflexible Kids: a 6-year Longitudinal Study of Parenting Style and the Development of Psychological Flexibility in Adolescents|journal=Journal of Youth Adolescence|date=2012|volume=41|issue=8|pages=1053–1066|doi=10.1007/s10964-012-9744-0}}</ref> [[Parenting styles#Authoritative parenting|Authoritative parenting styles]] seem to be associated with psychological flexibility in children. Authoritative parents tend to be more warm, fair, and encouraging than other parenting styles which may be why children raised by this style have more psychological flexibility. The children are encouraged to be independent and are supported, so they are able to adjust to situations that do not go as predicted.
===Work environment=== Psychological flexibility has been found to improve [[mental health]] and absence rates.<ref name="bondtheabilityofpsychologicalflexibilityandjobcontrol">{{cite journal|last=Bond|first=F.W.|author2=P.E. Flaxman|title=The Ability of Psychological Flexibility and Job Control to Predict Learning, Job Performance, and Mental Health|journal=Journal of Organizational Behavior Management|date=2006|volume=26|issue=1–2|pages=113–130|doi=10.1300/J075v26n01_05}}</ref> A mediating variable is [[job control (workplace)|job control]], which suggests that people feel they have more psychological flexibility when they have more control over their jobs.<ref name="bondtheinfluenceofpsychologicalflexibilityonworkredesign">{{cite journal|last=Bond|first=F.W. |author2=P.E. Flaxman |author3=D. Bunce|title=The Influence of Psychological Flexibility on Work Redesign: Mediated Moderation of a Work Reorganization Intervention|journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|date=2008|volume=93|issue=3|pages=645–654|doi=10.1037/0021-9010.93.3.645|pmid=18457492}}</ref> This is likely due to workers feeling less restricted by what they are allowed to do and more empowered to solve a problem.<ref name="bondtheinfluenceofpsychologicalflexibilityonworkredesign"/> A longitudinal study on psychological flexibility and job control showed that these variables predicted workers' mental health, [[job performance]], and even their ability to learn new software.<ref name="bondtheabilityofpsychologicalflexibilityandjobcontrol"/> The study demonstrates the power of psychological flexibility in the workplace as psychologically flexible workers have better mental health and job performance.<ref name="bondtheabilityofpsychologicalflexibilityandjobcontrol"/> Allowing workers more job control would likely increase work productivity as it would increase the workers' psychological flexibility.<ref name="bondtheabilityofpsychologicalflexibilityandjobcontrol"/> In leadership studies, flexibility, defined as "the ability to get along with different groups and adapt to the demands of many organizations," is one aspect of portability, or the ability to acquire skills and move from one company to the next.<ref name="hbrtheportableleader">{{cite news|last1=Petriglieri|first1=Gianpiero|title=The Portable Leader Is the New "Organization Man"|url=https://hbr.org/2017/08/the-portable-leader-is-the-new-organization-man|accessdate=August 19, 2017|work=Harvard Business Review|date=August 10, 2017}}</ref>
===Health=== The ability to cope and be flexible was positively associated with improved psychological health. Flexibility reduced depression, anxiety, and stress.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kato|first=T.|title=Development of the Coping Flexibility Scale: Evidence for the Coping Flexibility Hypothesis|journal=Journal of Counseling Psychology|date=2012|volume=59|issue=2|pages=262–273|doi=10.1037/a0027770}}</ref> An in-depth experiment analyzed the relationship between difficulty identifying and describing feelings (DIDF) and psychological flexibility for men undergoing cancer screenings. Results showed that DIDF and psychological flexibility were reliable predictors of mental health. However, psychological flexibility only predicted mental health when DIDF was involved. Psychological flexibility allowed participants to have a better understanding of the subtleties of pleasant and unpleasant emotions. This understanding allowed participants to identify and describe their feelings better, thus enhancing their mental health.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Landstra|first=J.B. |author2=J. Ciarrochi |author3=F.P. Deane |author4=R.J. Hillman|title=Identifying and Describing Feelings and Psychological Flexibility Predict Mental Health in Men with HIV|journal=British Journal of Health Psychology|date=2013|volume=18|issue=4|pages=844–857|doi=10.1111/bjhp.12026}}</ref>
A 2 year longitudinal study found that psychological flexibility helps with long-term emotional adjustment. People who are better at enhancing and suppressing their expression of emotions are less likely to be stressed over time.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bonanno|first=G.A.|author2=A. Papa |author3=K. Lalande |author4=M. Westphal |author5=K. Coifman |title=The Importance of Being Flexible: The Ability to Both Enhance and Suppress Emotional Expression Predicts Long-term Adjustment|journal=Psychological Science|date=2004|volume=15|issue=7|pages=482–487 |doi=10.1111/j.0956-7976.2004.00705.x |pmid=15200633}}</ref> People with higher psychological flexibility are also able to have greater endurance, higher pain tolerance, and a quicker recovery rate to baseline levels when experiencing physical pain.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Feldner|first=M.T. |author2=H. Hekmat |author3=M.J. Zvolensky |author4=K.E. Vowles |author5=Z. Secrist |author6=E.W. Leen-Feldner|title=The Role of Experiential Avoidance in Acute Pain Tolerance: A Laboratory Test|journal=Journal of Behavior Therapy and Experimental Psychiatry|date=2006|volume=37|issue=2|pages=146–158|doi=10.1016/j.jbtep.2005.03.002}}</ref>
==How to improve== Improvements can be made to psychological flexibility through training, such as through various forms of [[psychotherapy]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Greenberg |first1=Leslie S. |authorlink1=Les Greenberg |last2=Rice |first2=Laura North |last3=Elliott |first3=Robert |date=1993 |title=Facilitating emotional change: the moment-by-moment process |location=New York |publisher=[[Guilford Press]] |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=nWrOpUO6ku0C&pg=PA76 76] |isbn=0898629942 |oclc=27897484 |quote=Once we attend to our emotional feedback, our survival/[[Actualizing tendency|growth tendency]] ensures that we are constantly attempting to make the decision most advantageous to our well-being in terms of how we currently perceive ourselves and the situation. Thus the growth tendency is constantly pushing the organism toward adaptive flexibility and need satisfaction in a specific context. As will be noted later, therapy is a process of helping the client access and strengthen this tendency.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Kashdan |first1=Todd B. |last2=Rottenberg |first2=Jonathan |date=November 2010 |title=Psychological flexibility as a fundamental aspect of health |journal=[[Clinical Psychology Review]] |volume=30 |issue=7 |pages=865–878 |doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2010.03.001 |pmid=21151705 |pmc=2998793 |quote=We have mentioned empirically based interventions that describe the cultivation of flexibility as a therapeutic aim (for reviews, see Hayes, Follette, & Linehan, 2004). However even when psychological interventions do not explicitly discuss flexibility as an aim of treatment (e.g., behavioral activation, cognitive therapy, interpersonal psychotherapy), flexibility is such an integral part of psychological functioning that it is almost inevitable that it will in some way be impacted.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Fox |first1=Kieran C. R. |last2=Kang |first2=Yoona |last3=Lifshitz |first3=Michael |last4=Christoff |first4=Kalina |date=2016 |chapter=Increasing cognitive-emotional flexibility with meditation and hypnosis: the cognitive neuroscience of de-automatization |editor1-last=Raz |editor1-first=Amir |editor2-last=Lifshitz |editor2-first=Michael |title=Hypnosis and meditation: towards an integrative science of conscious planes |location=Oxford; New York |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |pages=191–220 |isbn=9780198759102 |oclc=948262934 |quote=Are there ways in which we can increase the flexibility and diversity of the cognitive and emotional aspects of our spontaneous thought? Practices geared toward changing both the content and process of spontaneous thought are as ancient as their scientific study is new—such techniques have existed for millennia and continue to be developed in modern clinical contexts.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hinton |first1=Devon E. |last2=Kirmayer |first2=Laurence J. |date=March 2017 |title=The flexibility hypothesis of healing |journal=[[Culture, Medicine and Psychiatry]] |volume=41 |issue=1 |pages=3–34 |doi=10.1007/s11013-016-9493-8 |pmid=27142641 |quote=In this paper, we argue that many forms of healing and psychotherapy may work by inducing positive psychological states marked by flexibility or an enhanced ability to shift cognitive sets.}}</ref>
===Acceptance and commitment therapy=== {{Main|Acceptance and commitment therapy}} The main goal of [[acceptance and commitment therapy]] (ACT) is to increase psychological flexibility. ACT is a form of therapy that aims to help people accept unavoidable events, identify actions that will lead to goals, and acknowledge thoughts rather than accepting or disregarding them.<ref name="Bach">{{cite journal|last=Bach|first=P.|author2=S.C. Hayes|title=The Use of Acceptance and Commitment Therapy to Prevent the Rehospitalization of Psychotic Patients: A Randomized Controlled Trial|journal=Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology|date=2002|volume=70|issue=5|pages=1129–1139|doi=10.1037/0022-006x.70.5.1129}}</ref> When psychological flexibility was targeted in one study of ACT, there was a stronger reduction in psychological distress.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Fledderus|first=M. |author2=E.T. Bohlmeijer |author3=J. Fox |author4=K. M. G. Schreurs |author5=P. Spinhoven|title=The Role of Psychological Flexibility in a Self-help Acceptance and Commitment Therapy Intervention for Psychological Distress in a Randomized Controlled Trial|journal=Behaviour Research and Therapy|date=2013|volume=51|issue=3|pages=142–151|doi=10.1016/j.brat.2012.11.007}}</ref> There are six core processes in ACT interventions: acceptance, cognitive defusion, self as context, being present, values, and committed action.<ref name="Gale">{{cite encyclopedia | last = Boulanger | first = Jennifer L. | last2 = Hayes | first2 = Steven C. | last3 = Lillis | first3 = Jason | authorlink2 = Steven C. Hayes | authorlink3 = Jason Lillis | editor-last = Fisher | editor-first = Gary L. | editor-last2 = Roget | editor-first2 = Nancy A. | title = Acceptance and Commitment Therapy | encyclopedia = Encyclopedia of Substance Abuse Prevention, Treatment, & Recovery | volume = 1 | pages = 4–7 | publisher = [[SAGE Publications]] | location = Thousand Oaks, CA | date = 2009 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=wPJ-39gVHE0C&pg=PT38}}</ref>
''Acceptance'' is taught in order to teach people to embrace their emotions, rather than trying to get rid of them.<ref name="Gale" /> An example of acceptance would be when people feel angry and then choose to focus on the anger and accept that they are angry, rather than trying to unleash their anger to get rid of it. ''Cognitive defusion'' teaches people to not take their thoughts as literal in order to decrease the believability of negative thoughts and increase flexibility to behave as they want.<ref name="Gale" /> An example of cognitive defusion would be when someone thinks "I am the worst," and then notices the thought for what it is—mere words—perhaps by saying to themselves "I am having the thought that I am the worst". This is in contrast to a [[cognitive therapy]] approach where the person might challenge the thought by thinking of things in which he or she excels.
''Self as context'' attempts to have people create an awareness of their own experiences without being attached to them.<ref name="Gale" /> This process is done in order to help people let go of specific content and experience themselves.<ref name="Gale" /> ''Being present'' teaches people to directly experience the world by paying attention to the moment and being aware.<ref name="Gale" /> An example of being present would be meditation and mindfulness.<ref name="Gale" />
''Values'' teaches people to take actions for chosen qualities.<ref name="Gale" /> An example of this is somebody who chooses to continue to improve on being a father (chosen quality) by reliving painful childhood memories about how his own father parented him (action). The purpose is not to encourage pain, but rather to allow people to deal with pain for a valued choice, such as being a good father).<ref name="Gale" /> Lastly, ''committed action'' teaches people to make changes in behavior in order for them to reach chosen qualities.<ref name="Gale" /> Committed action involves identifying psychological barriers that will interfere with short, medium, and longer term goals and then working through those barriers in order to reach the goals.<ref name="Gale" />
==See also== * [[Adaptive performance]] * [[Integrative complexity]] * [[Openness to experience]] * [[Psychological resilience]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox writer | name = Fuad Sami Haddad | honorific_suffix = A.B.N.S., F.R.C.S. (C), F.A.C.S. | image = Recent_photograph_of_Dr._Fuad_Sami_Haddad.jpeg | native_name = فؤاد سامي حداد | native_name_lang = ar | birth_date = {{birth date|1924|3|31}} | birth_place = [[Beirut]], Lebanon | death_date = {{death date and age|2015|10|9|1924|3|31}} | death_place = [[Beirut]], Lebanon | occupation = Doctor, [[Neurosurgeon]], Professor, Humanitarian | alma_mater = [[American University of Beirut]], [[Montreal Neurological Institute]] | nationality = Lebanese, Canadian }} '''Fuad Sami Haddad''' ({{lang-ar|فؤاد سامي حداد}}; March 31, 1924 – October 9, 2015) was a [[neurosurgeon]], humanitarian, and writer. He was born in [[Beirut]] and spent most of his life in [[Lebanon]]. ==Personal life and education== Haddad was born in [[Beirut]]'s Ain El Mraiseh neighborhood. He was raised between here and the Haouz Sa'atyeh (حوز سعتيه) neighborhood. His mother, Lamia Morcos (1896–1994) raised Haddad along with his five siblings. The son of [[Sami Ibrahim Haddad]], a doctor and writer, Haddad's dreams did not fall far from the proverbial tree.{{cite book|last=Matossian|first=Robert|date=1986|title=Modern Neurosurgical Giants: Fuad Sami Haddad|publisher=Elsevier|page=149-152|isbn=9780444010834}} He attended primary school at the [[Collège Protestant Français]] from 1928 to 1935 and secondary school at the International College of Beirut.{{cite website|title=Curriculum Vitae|last1=Haddad|first1=Fuad Sami|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B5hzsCxYITGOSnZzN2piWUtLc2c/view?usp=sharing|accessdate=March 26, 2018}} He received both his Bachelor of Arts in 1944 and his [[M.D.]] in 1948 from the [[American University of Beirut]]. Haddad subsequently completed his surgical residency at the [[Orient Hospital]]. He then began his neurosurgery residency under [[Wilder Penfield]] at the [[Montreal Neurological Institute]] on July 1, 1950.{{cite website|title=Neuro News: In Memoriam|url=https://publications.mcgill.ca/neuronews/2016/02/25/in-memoriam-4/|accessdate=March 26, 2018}} There, he completed fellowships in [[neuropathology]], [[neuro-anatomy]], and [[electroencephalography]].{{cite website|title=Fifty Years Ago|last1=Haddad|first1=Fuad Sami|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/1wgJLU_6bfa9rzL49daupZtnxrMYEO3HC/view?usp=sharing|accessdate=March 26, 2018}} He returned to Lebanon in 1955 as "the first neurosurgeon certified by the American Board of Neurological Surgery to practice in the Middle East and... the entire Arab world."{{cite journal|last1=Hitchon|first1=Patrick|last2=Haddad|first2=Souheil|last3=Afifi|first3=Adel|title=Obituary: Fuad Sami Haddad, 1924–2015|journal=Journal of Neurosurgery|date=January 27, 2017|volume=126|issue=4|page=1362-1363|url=http://thejns.org/doi/full/10.3171/2016.10.JNS162349|accessdate=March 25, 2018}} In 1956, he married Aida Nasir, and together they raised six children of their own: Georges, Souheil, Fadi, Nabih, Labib, and Janane—two of whom are practicing neurosurgeons.{{cite website|title=Hommage au Dr Fuad Sami Haddad|magazine=L'Orient-Le Jour|last1=Ghossain|first1=Antoine|url=https://www.lorientlejour.com/article/949157/hommage-au-dr-fuad-sami-haddad.html|accessdate=March 26, 2018}} ==Career== Upon his return to Lebanon, Haddad joined the faculty at the [[American University of Beirut]] and served the university until 2012. All the while, he kept a private practice where he "received patients from the Gulf States, Saudi Arabia, the Levant, North Africa, Turkey, and Iran." The [[Lebanese Civil War]] began in 1975, making it difficult for [[American University of Beirut]] students to pursue a medical residency in the United States of America. Even before this era, Haddad saw a need and filled it with a neurosurgical residency program that remains successful to this day.{{cite website|title=History|url=https://staff.aub.edu.lb/~webneuro/history.html|accessdate=March 25, 2018}} Furthermore, on November 24, 1963, Haddad and his brother, Farid Haddad, were the founding members of the Lebanese Chapter of the American College of Surgeons.{{cite website|title=Part I – Origins and Beginnings of the Lebanon Chapter of the American College of Surgeons|url=http://www.facs-lebanon.org/History |accessdate=March 26, 2018}} Both contributions to organized medicine in Lebanon marked great successes for practicing and future doctors who survived the war. Even during wartime, Haddad remained in Beirut as the only neurosurgeon serving the 450-bed American University Medical Center. "On a memorable spring weekend in 1976, he had to perform 13 craniotomies in a row for craniocerebral wounds. For 60 long hours he stood in the operating room mending the brain wounds of those unfortunate casualties." Near the end of the war, Haddad was able to serve as a visiting professor in schools such as the [[University of Chicago]], the [[University of Iowa]], the [[Cleveland Clinic]], the [[University at Albany, SUNY]], and the [[University of Arkansas]]. Haddad retired on February 1, 2012. =='Life under Fire'== In 1988, Haddad was invited to address the 38th Annual Meeting of the [[Congress of Neurological Surgeons]] on the state of neurosurgery in the Middle East.{{cite journal|last1=Haddad|first1=Fuad S.|title=Neurosurgery in the Middle East: Life under Fire|journal=Neurosurgery|date=August 1, 1989|volume=25|issue=2|page=303-311|url=https://academic.oup.com/neurosurgery/article/25/2/303/2748498|accessdate=March 30, 2018}} Haddad explains the differences in disease, as [[tuberculosis]] ravaged much of [[Iran]] while it was far less prominent, and therefore a lower diagnostic priority, in the United States. Additionally, Haddad addresses differences in societal stability, since he had spent much of his career working under fire during the [[Lebanese Civil War]]. He notes how the absence of telephone communication and electricity (at times for two to three weeks) made surgeries and [[post-operative]] care exceptionally difficult. Haddad then shares that there exist more Lebanese surgeons in [[Sao Paolo]], [[Brazil]] than in Lebanon. Lastly, to defend his reasons for staying in Lebanon while healthcare providers fled, he leaves no room for doubt that his heart, and hands, are dedicated to the people of Lebanon. He finishes his address with a story and a firm commitment to the people of [[Lebanon]]:
A further example is that of a veiled woman who entered my empty office on one of the worse days of the fighting. I wondered what brought her to me when everybody else, including my own secretary, was looking for shelter from bombs and snipers. Said she, ‘Doctor, I know these are trying days and everything is scarce. I have baked a few loaves of bread and thought you and your family might do with some of them.’ Indeed we had gone without bread for 3 or 4 days, with a family of six children. She offered me three loaves and left. She had walked over 5 miles to bring this bread to me. As long as there are people like these in Lebanon, I will stay to serve them, no matter what the price is, and I am confident that, like the phoenix who rose from his ashes, Lebanon will and shall rise.
==Honors== *Holder of the Lebanese Golden Order of the Cedar – Commander (1988) *Distinguished Service Award from the [[American University of Beirut]] Alumni Greater Baltimore Chapter (April 1998) *Golden Medal of the [[Lebanese Order of Physicians]] (March 10, 1999) *Distinguished Service Award from the [[Lebanese Order of Physicians]] (December 22, 2005) *Distinguished Award from the Lebanese Boy Scout Association (February 12, 2006) *Gold Medal from the [[Collège Protestant Français]] (May 19, 2006) *Medal of the Pioneer, in recognition of leadership, achievement, and promotion of skull base surgery from the Asian-Oceanian Skull Base Surgery Society (October 2, 2006) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} *[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Fuad_Haddad Researchgate: Fuad Sami Haddad] *[https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00701-016-2708-5 Professor Dr. Fuad Sami Haddad, BA, MD, FRCS (C), FACS] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Haddad, Fuad Sami}} [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:Lebanese physicians]] [[Category:Neurosurgeons]] [[Category:People from Beirut]]

'''HIV/AIDS''' was first detected in [[Canada]] in 1982. In 2014, there were approximately 75,500 (range between 63,400 and 87,600) people living with HIV/AIDS (a prevalence of 212 per 100,000) in Canada. This represents a 9.7% increase from the estimated 68,800 at the end of 2011. It was estimated that 16,020 persons were living with undiagnosed HIV at the end of 2014, representing 21% of all people living with HIV in Canada at that time<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/summary-estimates-hiv-incidence-prevalence-proportion-undiagnosed-canada-2014.html|title=Summary: Estimates of HIV incidence, prevalence and proportion undiagnosed in Canada, 2014|last=Canada|first=Public Health Agency of|last2=Canada|first2=Public Health Agency of|date=2015-11-25|website=aem|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref>. [[Mortality rate|Mortality]] has decreased due to medical advances against HIV/AIDS, especially [[Antiretroviral drug#Combination therapy|highly active antiretroviral therapy]] (HAART).
== Population groups == Women have accounted for 27% of new cases and now make up 20% of all cases.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/aids/|title=CBC News In Depth - AIDS|work=[[CBC.ca]]|accessdate=2008-12-01|date=2008-12-01}}</ref>
=== Aboriginal Canadians ===
HIV/AIDS prevalence is increasing most rapidly amongst [[aboriginal Canadians]], with 9% of new infections in 2005.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/aids/|title=CBC News In Depth - AIDS|work=[[CBC.ca]]|accessdate=2008-12-01|date=2008-12-01}}</ref>
A three-country study of HIV diagnoses between 1999 and 2008 showed higher HIV rates from heterosexual contact among aboriginals, especially women, than non-aboriginal people. This suggested a widening epidemic beyond conventional risk groups among aboriginals. The same study showed much higher rates of HIV diagnoses among aboriginal people in Canada than in Australia and New Zealand.<ref>[http://akneahr.ciet.org/publications/HIVandAIDS/ HIV and AIDS in Aboriginal Communities]. Anisnabe Kekendazone Network Environment for Aboriginal Health Research. Retrieved 2011-12-12.</ref><ref>Shea B, Aspin C, Ward J, Archibald C, Dickson N, McDonald A, Penehira M, Halverson J, Masching R, McAllister S, Tuhiwai Smith L, Kaldor JM, Andersson N (2011). ''[http://www.anac.on.ca/Documents/HIV/HIV%203C%20near%20final.pdf HIV diagnoses in indigenous peoples: comparison of Australia, Canada and New Zealand]''. International Health 3 (3): 193-198. [http://www.internationalhealthjournal.com/article/S1876-3413%2811%2900027-1/abstract ] {{doi|10.1016/j.inhe.2011.03.010}}</ref>
== Government policy == The [[Canadian government]] created the Federal Initiative to Address HIV/AIDS in Canada to provide [[funding]] for [[preventive medicine|prevention]] and [[Income Support|support]] programmes to assist vulnerable people as well as [[research]], [[surveillance]], public awareness and [[evaluation]]. The Federal Initiative is coordinated through [[Health Canada]], the [[Public Health Agency of Canada]], the [[Canadian Institutes of Health Research]] and [[Correctional Service Canada]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/aids-sida/index-eng.php|title=HIV/AIDS - Infectious Diseases|work=[[Public Health Agency of Canada]]|accessdate=2010-01-04}}</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = Jazzercise, Inc. | logo = [[File:Jazzercise_logo.png|250px|Jazzercise logo]] | type = Corporation | genre = | foundation = 1969 | founder = Judi Sheppard Missett | location_city = | location_country = | location = [[Carlsbad, California|Carlsbad]], [[California]] | origins = | key_people = | area_served = | industry = [[Physical fitness]] | products = | revenue = $93 million for fiscal year 2015<ref name="Jazz">[http://www.jazzercise.com/companyinfo.htm] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070104013103/http://www.jazzercise.com/companyinfo.htm |date=January 4, 2007 }}</ref> | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = 228 corporate staff<ref name="Jazz"/> | parent = | divisions = Jazzercise Apparel, JM DigitalWorks | homepage = [http://www.jazzercise.com www.jazzercise.com] [https://www.youtube.com/jazzerciseinc Jazzercise YouTube channel] | dissolved = | footnotes = }} [[File:Jazzercise Franchise Ann Arbor Michigan.JPG|thumb|Jazzercise franchise, [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]]]]
'''Jazzercise''' is a dance fitness [[franchising|franchise]] company founded by Judi Sheppard Missett in 1969 and headquartered in Carlsbad, California, United States.
Jazzercise combines dance, strength, and resistance training with popular music for a full-body workout. The company currently has over 8,300 franchisees worldwide in 32 countries.
==Early history==
Judi Sheppard Missett created Jazzercise in Chicago, Illinois in 1969 as a student at [[Northwestern University]]. She was teaching at a dance studio and noticed her classes had high dropout rates. Realizing students were attending for physical fitness and not to become highly technically proficient in dance, Shepard Missett began to hold "just for fun" classes that began with a jazz warmup. These classes were eventually renamed "Jazzercise."
==Growth and franchising==
Sheppard Missett's family moved to Carlsbad, California, where she taught classes in local rec centers. Jazzercise quickly took off in San Diego and Sheppard Missett trained new instructors herself. Many of those first instructors were in military families, so as they moved around the country, and the world, new populations were continually introduced to the program. Initially using VHS videos, Sheppard Missett was able to train franchisees from a distance and began to sell franchise rights for Jazzercise studios across the country.
==Jazzercise in popular media== In [[Ron Howard]]'s live-action movie adaptation of ''[[Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000 film)|How the Grinch Stole Christmas]],'' the Grinch's schedule has an hour booked for Jazzercise.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/2000/11/17/2000-11-17_jim_carrey_makes_one_mean_gr.html |accessdate=September 22, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
In the episode of ''[[Taxi (TV series)|Taxi]]'' entitled "Louie Goes Too Far", [[Andy Kaufman]] (playing Vic Ferrari) suggests to Christopher Lloyd (playing Jim) that he take up Jazzercise as a way of meeting beautiful women.
On ''[[The Golden Girls]]'', Bea Arthur (Dorothy) admits taking up Jazzercise in the episodes "The Stan Who Came to Dinner" and "The Audit".
In the ''[[Futurama]]'' episode "Parasite Lost", the parasitic worms are seen Jazzercising Fry's muscles.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0766131/quotes|title="Futurama" Parasites Lost (TV Episode 2001)|work=IMDb|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref>
The ''[[Flight of the Conchords (TV series)|Flight of the Conchords]]'' episode "New Zealand Town" of their second television series features a song called "Fashion is Danger", which is a parody of 1980s music and style, and contains a reference to Jazzercise.
"Jazzercise Instructor" is featured as a job in ''[[The Sims 2]]''.
In the third series of ''[[The Mighty Boosh (series 3)|The Mighty Boosh]]'', Howard Moon goes to Jazzercise classes.
In the ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]] ''episode "[[Bad Reputation (Glee)|Bad Reputation]]", a tape is found of [[Sue Sylvester]] Jazzercising to [[Olivia Newton-John]]'s "[[Physical (Olivia Newton-John song)|Physical]]". In the following season's episode "[[Sexy (Glee)|Sexy]]", [[Holly Holliday]] is shown teaching a jazzercise class in which [[Will Schuester]] participates.
In the ABC hit show ''[[The Goldbergs (2013 TV series)|The Goldbergs]]'', Beverly Goldberg is frequently portrayed referencing or stepping to Jazzercise.
On the October 9, 2012 episode of ''[[The Daily Show]]'', [[Jon Stewart]] references Jazzercise in his opening monologue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/411611#i0,p11,d0|title=Watch The Daily Show With Jon Stewart Online - Free at Hulu|work=Hulu|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref>
In 2018 alone, Jazzercise has been featured in ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.com/bodies/half-their-size-weight-loss-jazzercise/}}</ref> ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.harpersbazaar.com/culture/features/a14626590/history-boutique-fitness/}}</ref> and the Netflix series ''[[GLOW (TV series)|GLOW]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/glownetflix?lang=en}}</ref>
